derivation_boxes.content: Previous versions had larger uncertainties due to moduli freedom. v14.1 resolves this completely via TCS topological filter:

info_boxes.title: Proton Decay in GUT Theories
info_boxes.content: Grand Unified Theories predict that protons are unstable and decay on extremely long timescales (~10^34 years). The decay is mediated by superheavy gauge bosons with mass M_GUT ~ 10^16 GeV. The proton lifetime τ_p scales as (M_GUT)^4, making it extremely sensitive to the GUT scale.

info_boxes.title: Geometric Suppression: TCS G₂ Topology
info_boxes.content: The TCS (Twisted Connected Sum) G₂ manifold provides a natural suppression mechanism through cycle separation. Matter and Higgs fields localize on different associative 3-cycles, and the geodesic distance between them (d/R = 0.12) is fixed by the K = 4 matching fibres. This gives a suppression factor S = 2.125 that is a topological invariant, not a free parameter.

info_boxes.title: Parameter-Free Prediction
info_boxes.content: Unlike earlier versions of the theory, v14.1 eliminates all continuous free parameters in the proton decay calculation. The cycle separation is topologically fixed, the Pneuma condensate is uniquely stabilized by the racetrack potential, and the GUT scale is geometrically determined. The only remaining uncertainties are from standard QCD threshold corrections.

info_boxes.title: Experimental Status and Future Tests
info_boxes.content: Super-Kamiokande has established a lower bound of τ_p > 1.67 × 10^34 years for the p → e^+ π^0 decay channel. The PM prediction of 8.15 × 10^34 years is 4.9 times this bound, making it potentially testable at the next-generation Hyper-Kamiokande detector, which will have significantly improved sensitivity.

Apply the exponential suppression formula: M_GUT = M_Pl exp(-κ · 2π / g_GUT^2)
